Requirement: The system must allow users to generate decentralized identifiers (DIDs).
Users must be able to receive, store, and view verifiable credentials (VCs).
Users must be able to generate verifiable presentations (VPs).
Users must be able to share VPs via QR code or secure data transfer.
The app must display visual progress indicators (spinners/bars) for any operations taking longer than 500ms.
Users must authenticate using biometrics or device PIN to access the wallet.

Private keys must be generated using native secure hardware APIs.
Keys must never leave the secure module in plaintext.
Keys must be non-exportable and hardware-bound.
The backend must cryptographically verify signatures on VCs using W3C methods.
The system must validate VC revocation status during every verification request.
The system must support zero-knowledge proof generation for selective disclosure.
The system must enforce nonce-based or timestamp-based replay protection for all verification requests.
Users must be able to export an encrypted backup package of their credentials and keys.
Users must be able to restore credentials on a new device following re-authentication.
Administrators must be able to restore trust-registry and system configuration backups.
Backup packages must include integrity verification ( checksum or signature) to detect tampering
Administrators must be able to manage issuers, credential templates, and revocation lists.
The system must log issuance and verification events for auditing.
The system must provide automated test suites for DIDs, VCs, and ZKPs.
The system must expose health-check endpoints for monitoring component status.
The mobile app must integrate with platform-specific secure storage APIs.
Backend services must expose standardized REST or DIDComm-style interfaces.
The system must support online credential verification through the backend.
The system must support offline verification using QR-encoded VPs where possible.
The system must support trust-registry lookups to verify issuer legitimacy.
The mobile app must maintain a cached copy of the trusted ledger, as applicable to the end-users DID for offline validation.
The mobile UI must provide intuitive workflows requiring no more than three user actions per credential operation.
Users must receive clear warnings for revoked, expired, or invalid credentials.
The UI must meet basic ADA accessibility standards (contrast, readable text, screen-reader compatibility).
Users must be able to securely delete stored credentials.
The system must provide notifications when credentials are revoked or updated.
The system must allow users to review and manage app permissions and data-sharing preferences.
